CRS_DESC: Applying game theory to economic and financial markets and interactions in a diverse set of examples like reputation, herding, bubbles and crashes, auctions, strategic information revelation and information accumulation in markets. Witnessing the wide range of applications that is amenable to game theoretical analysis.

Application of econometric tools using standard econometric software packages for microcomputers; empirical applications to selected economic problems of estimation and inference.

CRS_DESC: The balance of payments, macroeconomic policy in an open economy, exchange rate determination, exchange rate systems, currency crises, international financial arrangements and monetary history.

CRS_DESC: Introduction and exploration of quantitative methods and data sources used for applied trade policy analysis.

Introduces the novel business model and important features associated with digital platforms and analyzes firms various competitive behavior and anticompetitive conducts in the digital space.

CRS_DESC: Vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Green's theorem, Divergence theorem, Stoke's theorem.

CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (MATH 126orMATH 127orMATH 129)'], 'alert': ['Note:Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture']}

CRS_DESC: Preparation for reading and writing proofs with applications from major branches of mathematics, focusing on axiomatic structures and transformations that preserve structure.

CRS_DESC: Systematic approach to solving non-standard and competition level math problems on inequalities, infinite sums and products, combinatorics, number theory and games.

CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (MATH 226orMATH 227orMATH 229)'], 'alert': ['Note:Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture']}

CRS_DESC: Sets; relations; groups; homomorphisms; symmetric groups; Abelian groups; Sylow's theorems; introduction to rings and fields.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (MATH 290orMATH 430orMATH 432)'], 'alert': ['Note:Register for lecture and discussion']}

CRS_DESC: The real number system, metric spaces, limits, continuity, derivatives and integrals, infinite series.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (MATH 290orMATH 430orMATH 432)'], 'alert': ['Note:Register for one lecture and discussion listed immediately following that lecture']}

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the theory of numbers, including prime factorization, congruences, primitive roots, N-th power residues, number theoretic functions and certain diophantine equations.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (MATH 225orMATH 235orMATH 245)']}

CRS_DESC: The Euclidean plane and its isometries. Models for the hyperbolic metric, isometries, linear fractional maps, geodesics. Spherical geometry.

CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (MATH 226orMATH 227orMATH 229) and 1 from (MATH 225orMATH 235)']}

CRS_DESC: Populations, permutations, combinations, random variables, distribution and density functions, conditional probability and expectation,; binomial, poisson, and normal distributions; laws of large numbers, central limit theorem. Prerequisite: Consent of Instructor.

a: Probability spaces; distributions and characteristic functions; laws of large numbers, central limit problems; stable and infinitely divisible laws; conditional distributions. b: Dependence, martingales, ergodic theorems, second-order random functions, harmonic analysis, Markov processes.

CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:MATH 410andMATH 471']}

Group fitness instruction incorporating a variety of training methods such as cycling, HITT (high intensity interval training), step, circuits; nutritional guidelines.
Introduction to distance running while training for a 5k, 10k or half marathon; gait biomechanics and running efficiency; injury prevention; nutrition guidelines.
Introduction to hiking; specific conditioning to develop muscle strength and endurance; equipment; various terrain, weather conditions, safety; environmental impact and trail etiquette.

Acquisition of backpacking knowledge and skills; conditioning plan; nutrition and equipment selection; ethics and environmental considerations; navigation, safety and wilderness first aid; trip planning.
Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to sand volleyball and related physical conditioning; rules and strategies; history and culture.

CRS_DESC: a: Introduction to beginning and intermediate volleyball skills, rules, game tactics, and strategies. Emphasis on the development of: passing, setting, hitting, serving, blocking, and digging.
b: Advanced techniques; focus on offenses and defenses used in game situations.

CRS_DESC: Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and intermediate players; rules, scoring, court etiquette, strategies; singles and doubles; practice and match play.
Introduction to pickleball; develop basic skills, techniques and fundamentals; rules, scoring, etiquette and strategies of play (singles/doubles play).
Fundamental instruction of archery technique for beginners and intermediates; historical origins; form; the shot cycle; mindfulness; scoring; equipment; sport specific training.
Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginning and intermediate players; rules, scoring strategies; singles and doubles; practices and match play.
Fundamental instruction of basic strokes for beginners and intermediate players; rules, scoring, strategies; footwork and court positioning; practical drills and games.
Fundamental instruction of skills and tactics specific to Futsal; rules; strategies; elements of play that differ from soccer; conditioning, drills and games.
Development of basic skills for beginners, intermediate and advanced players; rules, positioning elements of play, small group and team tactics; full field scrimmages.
Basic skills development and knowledge in stance, grip and swing mechanics; course strategy; use of woods, irons and putting; history rules and etiquette.
a: Basic skill development in dribbling, passing, shooting, rebounding and defense; rules, history, and etiquette; drills and full court games.
Instruction on the effects of stress as it relates to work, sport and academics; coping strategies are discussed and applied through physical conditioning interventions.
First aid safety education and infant, child, and adult CPR; demonstrated proficiency and successful completion of exam prepares students for Red Cross certification.

Introduction to coaching strategies; team management; philosophy; ethics; leadership. Methodologies in sport specific training; skill progression; conditioning; athlete motivation; budgeting; fundraising.

Skills and strategies of coaching principles promoting healthy lifestyle change. Motivational communication techniques; goal setting; designing safe, effective exercise program; health coach certification exam preparation.
Participation in the University's intercollegiate programs as sanctioned and governed by the PAC-10 conference and/or the NCAA. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: The philosophical foundations of modern political and economic thought, including economic rationality, neoclassical economics, free-market vs. socialist economies and behavioral economics.

CRS_DESC: Topics include economic models of human behavior and their limits; models of justice, morality and law, and the politics and administration of institutions.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_DESC: Explores the nature of justice, and how apparently conflicting ideals, such as freedom and equality, are to be balanced within a just society.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_DESC: Feminist perspectives on various political problems; evaluate and apply different analyses of complex social phenomena like patriarchy, misogyny and intersectionality.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_NAME: Moral Dilemmas in the Legal Domain
CRS_DESC: Philosophical theories of law and applications to controversies of importance to society and our legal system, such as free speech, civil disobedience, and selfdefense.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the aims and basic techniques of formal logic, including propositional and quantificational logic.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."], 'alert': ['Note:Register for lecture and discussion']}

CRS_NAME: Existentialism in Philosophy, Literature and Film
CRS_DESC: A study of existentialist philosophy and its influence in 19th and 20th century culture, including both literature and film. Focus on works by Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Camus, Sartre, Beauvoir, Dostoevsky, Godard, and others.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_DESC: Explores formal tools for thinking about uncertainty. In an uncertain world, how is it rational to form our beliefs, make decisions, and interact with others?
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_DESC: Explore the nature of interpersonal conflict: war, polarization, abuse, silencing, public reason, democracy, cancel culture and resistance.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

Examination of problems in metaphysics and/or epistemology. Conducted at the intermediate level.
Philosophical investigation of sense perception as it relates to issues in epistemology, metaphysics, the philosophy of mind, and the philosophy of science.
Philosophical theories about the nature of law, relations between law and morality, and analysis of normative concepts central to law, such as responsibility, punishment, negligence.
CRS_NOTE: {'alert': ['Note:Register for lecture and discussion']}

CRS_DESC: A systematic presentation of the main philosophical perspectives on the interactions between law and the social-political aspects of our lives.
The nature of man and society, the nature and justification of state and government, political rights and political obligation, justice and equality.
Elements of propositional and quantified modal logic and the logic of counterfactual conditionals with an eye to some of their applications in contemporary philosophy.

CRS_DESC: Examination of contemporary theories of mind and its place in the natural world.

CRS_DESC: Language within cognitive science: speech physiology and acoustics, language acquisition, reading, language disorders, perception and mental representation of words, linguistic diversity and computer analysis of speech.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."], 'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by theLINGdepartment but may qualify for major credit inPSYC. To register, enroll inLING 275.']}

CRS_DESC: Supervised Research with department faculty.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Experimental and theoretical aspects of human memory, perception, thinking, and language. Lectures, demonstrations, and individual experiments. Prerequisite: 100g or departmental approval.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Receptor processes and stimulus organization; traditional topics in the perception of objects, space, time. Laboratory demonstrations and exercises.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Principles involved in classical and operant conditioning. Concentration on basic causes of behavior; consideration of the relevance of simple behavioral laws to complicated human behavior.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Experimental research methods in psychology; nature and concepts of scientific method.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100and 1 from (PSYC 274orECON 317)']}

CRS_DESC: Non-experimental research methods in psychology. Observational, survey and data analysis exercises
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:(PSYC 100andPSYC 314)']}

CRS_DESC: Neural bases of behavior. Concentration on sensory and motor processes and the interaction of neural, chemical, and hormonal systems.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Child and adolescent behavior and associated theories; exploration of the continuity between child and adult behavior. Laboratory projects.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Genetic, physical, and social influences during adult years on perception, learning and memory, intelligence, personality, social roles, and normal and deviant behavioral patterns. Laboratory demonstrations and exercises.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Scientific perspective of close relationships: intimate relationships, friendships and others, evolutionary and biological bases of attraction and love, historical, social , cultural influences. Prerequisite: PSYC 100. (Duplicates credit in PSYC 359)
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100'], 'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_DESC: Theoretical and experimental analysis of human behavior. Social processes involved in attitudes, conformity, compliance, interpersonal perception, liking, affiliation, aggression, altruism, and group dynamics.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: The commonly diagnosed behavior pathologies; biological, social, cultural and developmental antecedents of abnormal behavior; principles of learning, perception and motivation, as they relate to psychopathology.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the scientist-practitioner model of clinical psychology, including research methods, psychological assessment and diagnosis, psychotherapeutic interventions, and treatment of special populations.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Genetic, biological, psychological, and sociological characteristics of those who evidence criminal behavior; theoretical formulations to be reviewed and appraised. Prerequisites: PSYC 100. Duplicates credit in former PSYC 463.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_NAME: Stress, Health, and the Mind-Body Connection
CRS_DESC: Introduction to psychological, biological and behavioral processes affecting physical health, including stress, coping with disease, health behaviors and socioeconomic and cultural influences on health.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100'], 'restriction': ['Restriction:Registration open to the following major(s): Health and the Human Sciences, Psychology, Social Sciences (Psychology)'], 'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_DESC: Experimental and theoretical aspects of how spoken and written language is produced and understood, learned during childhood, and affected by brain damage.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (LING 210orPSYC 100)'], 'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by theLINGdepartment but may qualify for major credit inPSYC. To register, enroll inLING 406.']}

CRS_DESC: Effects of brain damage on human behavior and abilities, particularly language, memory, and emotion.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100'], 'restriction': ['Restriction:Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Senior (fifth year)']}

CRS_DESC: Social, environmental, and physiological influences on behaviors associated with aggression, eating, reproduction, and sleep. Will focus on behavioral disorders such as addiction.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 314']}

CRS_DESC: Pharmo-chemical nature of the brain; diseases of the brain and drug treatments. Recommended preparation: background in biological psychology, biology and/or neuroscience.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100'], 'restriction': ['Restriction:Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Master Student, Doctoral Student'], 'alert': ['Note:Prior background in biological psychology, biology and/or neuroscience will be advantageous. It is also recommended that students be in Junior, Senior or higher class level standing.']}

CRS_DESC: Principles of cognitive development, learning, and motivation applied to the development of literacy; includes tutoring a child 2 hours per week. Prerequisite: PSYC 336L.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 336'], 'alert': ['Note:Principles of cognitive development; examining how infants and children learn across different domains, including physical reasoning, language aquisition, concept learning, and social cognition.']}

CRS_DESC: Psychometric and experimental approaches to the study of intelligence, problem solving, reasoning and creativity, including analysis of mental test construction and validity.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:(PSYC 100andPSYC 274)']}

CRS_DESC: The biological underpinnings supporting social, emotional, and cognitive development from infancy through adolescence; Focus on neuroscience to understand typical and atypical development, including psychopathology.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: The adolescent years from both an applied and a research-oriented perspective. Topics include physical, cognitive, and moral development; socialization; and sexual and sex-role development.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the major components of cognition (perception, memory, intelligence) in terms of the neural coding characteristic of the relevant brain areas.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_NAME: Neural Network Models of Social and Cognitive Processes
CRS_DESC: Introduction to using neural network or connectionist models to simulate cognitive, social, emotional and motivational processes; basic concepts and tools in computational neuroscience.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: I/O Psychologists develop and apply scientifically supported solutions to the workplace. "Industrial" deals with human resource functions, and "Organizational" with psychological aspects of the organization. Prerequisite: PSYC 100. Recommended preparation: PSYC 316.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_NAME: Psychology of Marriage and the Family
CRS_DESC: Theories and research on family relationships across the life span, including research methods, cultural and developmental perspectives, communication, conflict, attachment, individual psychopathology, and family violence.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: A comprehensive overview of the assessment, diagnosis and treatment of individuals diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder.
Neuroscientific and psychological perspectives that investigate the basis of happiness and well-being.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:PSYC 100']}

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: {'restriction': ['Restriction:Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior']}

CRS_NAME: Classic and Modern Statistical Methods I
CRS_DESC: An introduction to classic statistical techniques as well as modern robust methods for dealing violations of standard assumptions.

CRS_NOTE: {'restriction': ['Restriction:Registration open to the following major(s): Applied Psychology', 'Restriction:Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student']}

CRS_DESC: Problems and theories of the person in the social context. Person perception, interpersonal relations, attitude dynamics, social systems.
Study of psychopathology: in-depth survey of theory and research concerning psychological disorders; introduction to diagnosis. (One of 4 clinical psychology core courses: 514, 515, 619, 620.)

Study of clinical assessment: test construction, measurement and predicition of behavior, major cognitive and personality assessment instruments. (One of 4 clinical psychology core courses: 514, 515, 619, 620.)

Theory and research on effective teams and characteristics of strong leaders. Negotiation, morale-building, managing expectancies, utilization of cultural diversity as a strength. Open only to M.S., Applied Psychology students.

CRS_DESC: Focus is on professionalism topics and skills central to developing as a clinical scientist, explored within a cultural context.

CRS_DESC: Provides a broad introduction to the social science methods UX researchers most commonly use, including qualitative approaches, and quantitative approaches.

Review of theories of cognitive development. Analysis of research on brain functioning, perception, memory, language, reasoning and academic skills from birth to adolescence.
Regional organization and systems of the mammalian nervous system and their functions.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to scientific data analysis; fundamentals of data structures and algorithms; specialized algorithms used in the sciences; challenges posed by large scientific data sets.

Applications of the mathematical, statistical and computational sciences to data from molecular biology. Statistics for genomic sequence data: DNA sequence assembly, significance of alignment scores, hidden Markov models, genetic mapping, models of sequence evolution and microarray analysis.

CRS_DESC: Analysis of forces acting on particles and rigid bodies in static equilibrium; equivalent systems of forces; friction; centroids and moments of inertia; introduction to energy methods.

CRS_DESC: Statistical methods for building intelligent and adaptive systems that improve performance from experiences; Focus on theoretical understanding of these methods and their computational implications. Explores fundamental techniques such as recursion, Fourier transform ordering, dynamic programming for efficient algorithm construction. Examples include arithmetic, algebraic, graph, pattern matching, sorting, searching algorithms.

CRS_DESC: Examines key aspects of information retrieval as they apply to search engines; web crawling, indexing, querying and quality of results are studied.

Course outlines the process of creating images from 3D models. Includes transformations, shading, lighting, rastorization, texturing, and other topics.

CRS_DESC: Basic concepts in information security and privacy; implications of security and privacy breaches; security and privacy policies, threats and protection mechanisms; security and privacy laws, regulations and ethics.

CRS_NAME: Principles of Programming for Data Science
CRS_DESC: Programming in Python for retrieving, searching and analyzing data from the Web. Learning to manipulate large data sets.

CRS_NAME: Research Methods and Analysis for User Studies
CRS_DESC: Introduction to research methods and data analysis techniques for human subject research; experimental research design, correlational research, data analysis, ensuring validity and ethics.

Background in computer security preferred. Recommended previous courses of study include computer science, electrical engineering, computer engineering, management information systems and/or mathematics.

Assurance that an information system will behave as expected; assurance approaches for fielding secure information systems; case studies. Recommended preparation: Prior degree in computer science, electrical engineering, computer engineering, management information systems and/or mathematics. Some background in computer security preferred.

CRS_DESC: Privacy concerns in healthcare; current law and regulations; existing and emerging technologies shaped by ethics, privacy considerations and medical implications; special attention given to genomic data.

Big data informatics fundamentals. Data lifecycle; the data scientist; machine learning; data mining; NoSQL databases; tools to store, process, analyze large data sets on clusters.

Function and design of modern storage systems, including cloud; data management techniques; data modeling; network attached storage, clusters and data centers; relational databases; the map-reduce paradigm.
Practical applications of machine learning techniques to real-world problems. Uses in data mining and recommendation systems and for building adaptive user interfaces.

CRS_DESC: Data mining and machine learning algorithms for analyzing very large data sets. Emphasis on System Building with Spark. Case studies.

CRS_DESC: Student teams working on external customer data analytic challenges; project/presentation based; real client data and implementable solutions for delivery to actual stakeholders; capstone to degree.

CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:EE 457andEE 477']}

CRS_DESC: Introduction to strategies for promoting health and wellness. Includes self monitoring of health risk behavior, goal setting, and behavior changes.
Nutrition as it relates to health promotion across the lifespan and disease prevention. Discussion of nutrients, factors affecting food choices, food safety and global nutrition issues.
Introduction to concepts of global health and disease control. Issues of globalization, global governance, emerging diseases, infectious disease treatment, and outbreak challenges.
Individual research apprenticeship in health related fields under supervision of a departmental faculty member. Graded CR/NC. Departmental approval.

CRS_DESC: Intermediate statistics for health behavior studies; topics include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression, and use of computer software in data analysis.
CRS_NOTE: {'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."]}

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the design, conduct and evaluation of health behavior research studies; quantitative and qualitative approaches to research and analysis. Recommended preparation: HP 340L

CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (HP 200orHP 270)'], 'generaleducation': ["General Education:This course satisfies the university's general education requirement."], 'multicultural': ["Diversity:This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement."], 'alert': ['Note:This course carries GE credit but it is intended for a specific group of students rather than a general student audience. CRS_NOTE: {'multicultural': ["Diversity:This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement."]}

Overview of causative factors and demographic distributions of the major chronic diseases in the western world; edpidemiologic concepts and research designs. Recommended preparation: HP 320

Survey of the development of healthy and the prevention of health-risk behaviors during adolescence. Prevention and promotion techniques will be explored emphasizing cultural differences.

CRS_NOTE: {'alert': ['Note:This course provides an up close and personal perspective on modern health care delivery in the U.S. A host of facilitators in active medical practice focus on practical knowledge and skills for those planning a career in health care.']}

CRS_DESC: An introduction to professionalism and skills required in the practice of medicine and careers in health care.
CRS_NOTE: {'alert': ['Note:Introduction to the skills required and expected of health care professionals, to translate skills like communication, conflict resolution, and team management to the practice of medicine.']}

CRS_DESC: An exploration of the practice of primary care medicine which will discuss what primary care is and differences between primary care and specialist care.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:MEDS 220'], 'alert': ['Note:If you have not taken prerequisiteMEDS 220and would like to take this course, please contactmhcs@usc.edufor prerequisite waiver considerarion.']}

CRS_NOTE: {'alert': ['Note:This course explores the development and role of health care systems in industrialized countries, with a focus on that of the United States. This includes a review of the history of medicine to better understand the current state of health care today and the dilemmas presented.']}

CRS_DESC: Examines collective experiences of historical trauma in various populations through a macro lens, focusing on promotion of mental health equity in impacted populations.
CRS_NOTE: {'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by thePBHSdepartment but may qualify for major credit inMEDS. To register, enroll inPBHS 302.']}

CRS_DESC: Examine the impact of adversity experienced during childhood with social development and neurodevelopment throughout the lifecycle and the bi-directional relationship with society through a trauma lens.
CRS_NOTE: {'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by thePBHSdepartment but may qualify for major credit inMEDS. To register, enroll inPBHS 303.']}

CRS_DESC: Explores ways that changing climate affects individual and collective mental health, including concepts related to building individual and collective resilience to environmental threats.
CRS_NOTE: {'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by thePBHSdepartment but may qualify for major credit inMEDS. To register, enroll inPBHS 304.']}

CRS_DESC: Explores evidence-based interdisciplinary team care in healthcare, focusing on roles of mental health professionals on these teams and communication amongst professionals in different disciplines.
CRS_NOTE: {'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by thePBHSdepartment but may qualify for major credit inMEDS. To register, enroll inPBHS 306.']}

CRS_NAME: Dynamics of Power and Gender-Based Violence
CRS_DESC: Examines dynamics of gender-based harm and impacts to individuals, communities and society through sociocultural theoretical approaches through course lecture, group discussion, self-reflection and critical thinking.
CRS_NOTE: {'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by thePBHSdepartment but may qualify for major credit inMEDS. To register, enroll inPBHS 307.']}

CRS_DESC: Explores the science behind altruism, volunteerism, compassion and how helping others impacts individuals physically, psychologically and behaviorally through lectures, projects and experiential learning.
CRS_NOTE: {'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by thePBHSdepartment but may qualify for major credit inMEDS. To register, enroll inPBHS 305.']}

CRS_DESC: Introduction to human anatomy and physiology in relation to common disease processes, and an examination of how technology has transformed western medicine throughout history.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221)']}

CRS_NAME: The Brain in Health and Disease
CRS_DESC: Study of the human brain through the lens of disease using illustrative case studies, current imaging techniques and potential future treatment for neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.
CRS_PREREQ: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A)
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 103orCHEM 105AorCHEM 115A)']}

CRS_DESC: The neurochemistry of psychiatric illness and addiction, introduction to brain and nervous system biochemistry, anatomy and disease states. Covers prescribed medications and drugs of abuse.
CRS_PREREQ: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A)
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 103orCHEM 105AorCHEM 115A)']}

CRS_DESC: Overview of the cellular make-up of the human skeleton, the functions of bones, clinical application of this knowledge towards bone-related diseases, and introduction to technological advances in orthopedic surgery.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221)']}

CRS_DESC: A theoretical basis of laboratory approaches that help the biomedical or physician scientist in understanding the etiology of disease and targeting disease processes.
CRS_PREREQ: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A)
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 103orCHEM 105AorCHEM 115A)']}

CRS_DESC: An examination of frequently treated diseases with the greatest impact on society. Involvement of medical specialists as guests.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221)']}

CRS_DESC: Overview of the biological processes involved in vertebrate development and regeneration, including the cellular interactions and signal transduction pathways guiding organ development and repair.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221)'], 'crosslist': ['Crosslist:This course is offered by theSCRMdepartment but may qualify for major credit inMEDS. To register, enroll inSCRM 386.']}

CRS_DESC: Basic medical and developmental concepts that are important during the infant, child and adolescent phases of life, as well as guest lectures from health care professionals in the pediatric field.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:MEDS 220']}

CRS_DESC: Emphasizes the team-based approach used by forensic scientists, medical examiners and coroners to investigate the circumstances and determine the cause/manner of death. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221) andMEDS 220'], 'restriction': ['Restriction:Registration open to the following class level(s): Sophomore, Junior, Senior, Senior (fifth year)'], 'alert': ['Note:Dr. Lakshmanan Sathyavagiswaran is the former Chief Medical Examiner-Coroner for Los Angeles County, who has handled many High Profile cases. Also learn how he and his staff responded to several air/train disasters, 1992 Los Angeles Riots, and 1994 Northridge Earthquake.']}

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the spectrum of surgical care, taught by surgeons, with the goal of developing an appreciation of the role that surgery plays in society. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a and MEDS 220. Open only to juniors and seniors.
CRS_PREREQ: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a) and MEDS 220

CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (BISC 220orBISC 221)'], 'alert': ['Note:Introduction to the spectrum of clinical and scientific issues surrounding contemporary cancer care, molecular diagnostics, genomic medicine, modern therapeutics, and community/patient engagement.']}

CRS_DESC: Principles of emergency medical services, ranging from pre-hospital care and advanced life-saving, to minor injuries and illnesses. CRS_DESC: Critical issues in international control and treatment of malaria. Exploration of biological and epidemiological fundamentals of human-parasite interaction including dynamics of transmission among populations.

CRS_DESC: A contemporary survey of the methods used to monetize music through licensing/media placement, covering music publishing, songwriter agreements, performance rights and licenses for traditional/new media. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (MUIN 270orMUIN 272)']}

CRS_DESC: An intermediate/advanced-level survey of music copyright law, artist contract analysis, infringement case studies as they affect modern/emerging business models and global music licensing.
CRS_NOTE: {'prereq': ['Prerequisite:1 from (MUIN 270orMUIN 272)']}

Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

CRS_DESC: An exploration of the most current and effective marketing strategies and online branding tools for promoting, monetizing, and sustaining the career of the independent creative artist. Prerequisites: MUIN 270 or MUIN 272x.

CRS_DESC: A survey of the presentation of the live musical experience. Both classical and popular concert presentation will be examined including venue selection, promotion and security.

CRS_DESC: Focus on planning, booking, marketing, promoting, ticketing and operating a festival in an ever-changing marketplace.
